channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: You CAN see your grandparents, Boris Johnson tells Britons as he announces lockdown relaxation rules
item.description: After two months of stringent restrictions in the UK, grandparents will now be able to see their children and grandchildren - while groups of six friends or family members can gather.

item.title: Minneapolis declares a state of emergency as protests over George Floyd's death spread across US
item.description: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey declared a local emergency Thursday night due to civil disturbances, as the National Guard and state troopers have been drafted in to the city.

item.title: Female zookeeper is attacked by a LION and suffers serious wounds to her neck and head
item.description: The 35-year-old was found unconscious in the lion's enclosure at around 10.20am at Shoalhaven Zoo, in North Nowra.

item.title: Tesla CEO Elon Musk earns first performance-based compensation worth more than $700million
item.description: Tesla confirmed Thursday that the company had hit financial benchmarks that would trigger CEO Elon Musk's first compensation package worth more than $700million.

item.title: Four more accuse Harvey Weinstein of rape in new lawsuit as 68-year-old serves 23-year prison term
item.description: Harvey Weinstein (left), the 68-year-old film mogul serving a 23-year prison term near Buffalo, New York, for rape (bottom right inset), is named in a new lawsuit, as is his brother, Bob Weinstein (top right).

item.title: Man dies after 'rock throwing incident' in grounds of Kent castle
item.description: The Kent and Essex Serious Crime Directorate has launched an investigation after a man died in a 'disturbance' where it was reported rocks were being thrown.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: R-rate still near one as death toll hits 37,837
item.description: The Department of Health has announced the deaths of 377 more coronavirus patients while a blood-testing survey suggests some 4.5million people have had the virus.

item.title: Ministers consider rapid coronavirus tests at airports in bid to restart holidays abroad
item.description: Scientists and officials are looking at whether coronavirus tests could be taken both before leaving and re-entering Britain to avoid quarantine that could help give a boost to the aviation industry.

item.title: Quarantining travellers for 14 days will cost UK economy £650million a WEEK
item.description: Experts fear the two-week quarantine will wipe out the UK summer holiday season, which brings in £9billion in a normal year, leading to tens of thousands of lost jobs, say business leaders.

item.title: Johnny Cash's granddaughter is called a 'liberal p****' for wearing a face mask in Nashville store
item.description: Though her father Johnny Cash was famed for his rebellious ways, Rosanne, 65, said her daughter was sensibly following government guidance when she was heckled in Green Hills.

item.title: Kate Garraway claps for carers as husband battles coronavirus
item.description: The Good Morning Britain presenter, 53, also took to Instagram to share an update about her spouse's COVID-19 battle and admitted she was emotional over the fact it could be the final one.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... test and trace in the UK
item.description: 'When 2,456,000 people say they have Covid and were in contact with you, we can't take any chances, Mr Cummings'

item.title: Britain's biggest solar farm gets green light in Kent countryside despite fears it will harm area
item.description: The £450million project Cleve Hill solar park will be capable of generating enough electricity to power more than 91,000 homes through producing 350 megawatts.
item.media:credit: Hive and Wirsol Energy/Planning Inspectorate National Infrastructure Planning

item.title: Police launch probe into claims a mother died after NHS staff gave her a paracetamol overdose
item.description: Police have launched an investigation into claims a mother of two Laura Higginson died after NHS doctors gave her an accidental overdose of paracetamol whilst being treated for pneumonia.

item.title: Schoolboy gymnast, nine, vows to perform again just days after losing part of his leg in a crash
item.description: Little 'warrior' Max Clark, 9, was rushed to hospital after he was struck by a bike while in Hull on Monday - the first time he and his family had left the house since coronavirus lockdown began.

item.title: ISIS says coronavirus is 'God's divine punishment'
item.description: In an audio broadcast posted on one of the militants' websites yesterday, the person on the tape identified himself as IS spokesman Abu Hamzah al-Quraishi.

item.title: Half of Brits have gained weight during lockdown and 14% haven't left their house in a week
item.description: The study of more than 2,250 people by King's College London comes after NHS data revealed severely overweight people were 40 per cent more likely to die from COVID-19.

item.title: Britons are warned don't water your lawn as driest May on record raises fears of hosepipe bans
item.description: Yorkshire Water has asked its three million households to cut their water usage in the driest May in 124 years. Britain has only seen an average of 1.25in (31.8mm) of rain across so far this month.

item.title: Employers will have to pay a quarter of furloughed staff's wages from August
item.description: Chancellor Rishi Sunak's announcement comes as 8.4 million workers in the UK are now furloughed to a cost of £15billion to date, according to plans devised by HM Revenue & Customs.

item.title: Care home lockdown plan was rejected by ministers at the peak of the coronavirus outbreak last month
item.description: Downing Street received an 11-point plan proposing 'a further lockdown of care homes' from PHE on April 28. The moves were not included in the action plan unveiled by Health Secretary Matt Hancock.

item.title: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Should you raise your child to be a burger babe or a kung fu kid?
item.description: CHRISTOPHER STEVENS: Robin and Rin won the first round, with a regime based on martial arts training and chess. They aim to raise 'scholar-warriors'.

item.title: Springwatch's newest star! Chris Packham's step-daughter Megan McCubbin is a big hit with viewers
item.description: Chris Packham's decision to invite his step-daughter Megan McCubbin on to BBC2's Springwatch was met with approval. The pair have been isolating together during the COVID-19 crisis.

item.title: Darlington MP admits to taking train 225 miles to the North East while showing covid-19 symptoms
item.description: Peter Gibson, the Conservative MP for Darlington, County Durham revealed on social media over the weekend that he travelled from London to self-isolate in the North East in March.

item.title: BAZ BAMIGBOYE: Life is a Dolly mixture for Queen Imelda Staunton on stage and screen
item.description: BAZ BAMIGBOYE: The decision to shift the show was taken because of the impact of the pandemic on the theatre industry; and to allow Staunton to honour her filming commitments to The Crown.

item.title: Bernie Ecclestone, 89, and his pregnant wife Fabiana Flosi, 44, stroll hand in hand
item.description: The Formula One tycoon stepped out hand-in-hand with Fabiana Flosi, 44, as he prepares to become a father to his first son and fourth child in July.

item.title: Donald Trump claims social media has anti-conservative bias
item.description: The order could open Twitter, Facebook and Google to lawsuits by diluting legal protection which stops them from being liable for posts on their platforms.

item.title: BBC appoint former head of global news to review impartiality policy
item.description: Richard Sambrook, a former director of BBC global news, will be tasked with assessing whether the corporation's social media accounts are going against its impartiality policy.
item.media:credit: BBC News & Current Affairs via G

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Clap for Carers occurs for maybe the last time
item.description: People all over the country have been taking to their doorsteps, balconies and windows to cheer and applaud NHS staff and key workers over the past ten weeks, amid the fight against coronavirus.

item.title: Prosecutors warn there is 'evidence that does not support criminal charge' in George Floyd's killing
item.description: Hennepin County attorney Mike Freeman condemned the actions of white cop Derek Chauvin as 'horrific and terrible' but added there was 'other evidence that does not support a criminal charge'.

item.title: And the winner is... After a ten-week countdown, Brian Viner reveals his favourite movie of all time
item.description: BRIAN VINER: This week, I conclude the ten-week countdown of my 100 favourite English-language films. So I'm going to champion my Top 10 and to remind you of the full list.

item.title: Christian Cooper, victim of Central Park Karen ACCEPTS her apology
item.description: Harvard graduate Christian, 57, had been bird watching in an area of the park known as The Ramble over the Memorial Day weekend when he saw Amy Cooper walking her unleashed dog.

item.title: Steph McGovern claims Donald Trump tried to bully a producer during BBC Breakfast interview in 2012
item.description: Steph McGovern, 37, told Susannah Constantine's podcast that Donald Trump threatened her producer, saying 'You've got a good career here. You want to keep it that way'.

item.title: Political drama as sharp as a whip: Patrick Marmion reviews This House
item.description: PATRICK MARMION: 'This House' is the Westminster political drama that keeps on giving. But BBC iPlayer's 'Unprecedented' and NBC's 'Hairspray' starring Ariana Grande need a little more work.

item.title: Abortions by post got rushed approval for lockdown, but now troubling stories are emerging
item.description: Courtney Barnes, 27, from Kent, (pictured) was sent kit to terminate her pregnancy without medical supervision, as emergency pandemic legislation means women are not required to attend a clinic.

item.title: Britain offers passport holders in Hong Kong visa-free travel
item.description: Britain offered stronger rights to its passport holders in Hong Kong yesterday after China rubber-stamped controversial new security laws.

item.title: How to stop chopped apples from going brown
item.description: A mum has revealed her simple tricks for preventing chopped apples from turning brown and making sure her fussy five-year-old daughter eats her fruit hours after it's been sliced.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Prince William addresses mental health issue
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge, 37, called for 'preparing for a very different mindset for mental health' as Britain slowly emerges out of a draconian 10-week lockdown imposed to fight coronavirus.

item.title: Wild cockatoos excel in intelligence tests, countering theory living with humans makes birds smarter
item.description: A longheld theory that animals raised in captivity perform better in cognitive testing may need to be rethought, after wild cockatoos matched the performance of lab-raised ones in testing.

item.title: Record 8,500 foreign-born criminals are back on the streets and still awaiting deportation
item.description: Findings will renew fears Home Office is failing to tackle the problem. Tory MP Philip Hollobone said Government ministers need to get a grip on this situation.
item.media:credit: Chris McAndrew / UK Parliament (Attribution 3.0 Unported (CC BY 3.0))

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Pubs could reopen if social distancing at 1m
item.description: Albert's Schloss in Manchester has installed perspex screens and thermal screening so it can reopen doors this weekend amid fears most pubs will close down unless they reopen before September.

item.title: USAF F-15E Strike Eagle warplanes stop off at RAF Lakenheath after flying missions over Syria
item.description: The elite American warplanes are on their way home to Mountain Home base in Idaho after stopping by the Suffolk base which hosts USAF units and personnel earlier this week.

item.title: World's oldest man Bob Weighton dies aged 112
item.description: The world's oldest man, Bob Weighton has died from cancer aged 112. Mr Weighton, from Alton, Hampshire became the world's oldest man after the previous record died in February.

item.title: Nearly 20 UK council areas have NOT yet seen their coronavirus peaks
item.description: North Somerset, Preston, Doncaster and Carlisle are enduring their worst weeks so far, according to data from the Office for National Statistics. The data reveals a considerable degree of variation on a local level.

item.title: Premier League action to be shown on terrestrial television for the first time in the UK
item.description: The Premier League announced that all 92 remaining matches will be broadcast live in the UK by the League's existing broadcast partners - Sky Sports, BT Sport, BBC Sport and Amazon Prime.

item.title: How to make stale bread fresh again: Mum's genius trick transforms her old loaf in MINUTES
item.description: A mother has shared her 'miracle' trick for reviving bread that is going stale - and all you need is a tap. The mother posted the idea on Facebook, where it was quickly heralded as 'genius'.

item.title: Worshippers at Jewish temple 'used cannabis', analysis shows
item.description: Worshippers at a Jewish temple dating back more than 2,700 years likely smoked cannabis during cultic ceremonies, ancient Israeli limestone reveals.

item.title: DOUGLAS MURRAY: It's not the first time Emily Maitlis has forced her bosses to apologise for her
item.description: DOUGLAS MURRAY: Newsnight presenter, Emily Maitlis (pictured), was visibly angered by Boris Johnson's colleagues describing him as a 'fighter'.

item.title: White man kicked out of office building after threatening to call the police on black businessmen
item.description: Tom Austin, pictured, thought a group of African American men were using their shared office gym unlawfully. They were a group of entrepreneurs working out of the same Minneapolis building.

item.title: Trump raises fears of new trade war with China by announcing White House press conference
item.description: The Trump administration may soon expel thousands of Chinese graduate students enrolled at U.S. universities and impose other sanctions against Chinese officials.

item.title: Harry Dunn's family launch private prosecution against Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab
item.description: Harry Dunn's parents are accusing Dominic Raab of misconduct in public office and perverting the course of justice after suspect Anne Sacoolas returned to the US claiming diplomatic immunity.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Dentists to reopen from 8 June
item.description: Sara Hurley, the Chief Dentistry Officer (CDO) for England, said dentists can start taking routine appointments in just 10 days - with some changes to surgeries to prevent the virus spreading.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Several' vaccines could be ready by end of year
item.description: AstraZeneca CEO Pascal Soriot said it was on track to produce millions of its COVID-19 jab - developed by Oxford University researchers and called AZD1222 - by September.

item.title: Fewer than 200 cars were built in the UK during April lockdown
item.description: All were 'premium, luxury and sports cars' that 'had been assembled prior to shutdowns with only finishing touches needed', according to the SMMT.

item.title: Climate could cause abrupt British vegetation changes
item.description: Climate change will cause an overall increase in the amount of vegetation growing in Britain, a new research paper from scientists at the University of Exeter predicts.

item.title: One in ten Covid-19 patients with diabetes die within a week of being admitted to hospital
item.description: A study looked at the 1,300 patients in France with diabetes after they were admitted to hospital with Covid-19. Almost a third of patients either died or needed mechanical ventilation by day seven.

item.title: Coral-coated shipwreck found off the coast of Mexico crashed into the 'Nightmare reef' 200 years ago
item.description: A coral-coated shipwreck has been found off the coast of Mexico that has laid hidden beneath the surface for over 200 years. Researchers believe it is a British ship that crashed into ' Nightmare reef .'

item.title: Facebook verifying identities behind 'high-reach' accounts that show signs of 'inauthentic' behavior
item.description: Facebook will require accounts that are 'high-reach,' meaning they often go viral, to undergo verification by showing a form ID if they're found to be exhibiting signs of 'inauthentic' behavior.

item.title: Family of rail worker, 47, who died after being spat on do not hold much hope for prosecution
item.description: The March 22 attack by a passenger in Victoria station, central London who claimed he had coronavirus was not reported to police until May 11, a month after Belly Mujinga, her husband said.

item.title: TOM UTLEY: I got off lightly during lockdown but here's why I yearn for liberation day
item.description: TOM UTLEY: I've never been much of a one for sunbathing. I've long lost the urge to travel, since airports became such a nightmare, and I've always hated discos.

item.title: Coronavirus: Drug for children's disease had promising results
item.description: Ruxolitinib is a drug used to treat HLH, a severe systemic inflammatory syndrome in children that can be fatal and scientists believe it can prevent cytokine storms in coronavirus patients.

item.title: George Floyd left Texas prison to start new life in Minneapolis
item.description: George Floyd moved to Minneapolis in 2014 shortly after being released from prison in Houston, Texas following an arrest for aggravated robbery with a gun. Floyd died on Monday.

item.title: Wearing face masks at home may be the best way to stop COVID-19
item.description: Researchers from the Beijing Centre for Disease Prevention and Control say a face mask indoors only works to slow the infection rate in family members before symptoms develop.

item.title: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Stephen Bayley wants us all to live like peasants when lockdown ends
item.description: SEBASTIAN SHAKESPEARE: Bayley, who was the first director of the Design Museum in London, says lockdown could make our lives more satisfying - if we revert to a 'peasant' outlook.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Civil liberties groups slam test and trace fine
item.description: Civil liberties groups have today slammed threats by health chiefs to fine Britons who do not obey the 14-day test and trace isolation rules - which have been dubbed a 'draconian intrusion of privacy'.

item.title: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: I'd rather a local lobster than a fresh dressed Cromer bat...
item.description: RICHARD LITTLEJOHN: In one of the more bizarre developments, the animal rights brigade, are trying to force the annual Cromer and Sheringham Crab and Lobster Festival to turn vegan...

item.title: JAN MOIR: The Duchesses' duel of the tights is all a game of thrones
item.description: JAN MOIR: Can it be true that the beautiful wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle took place without anyone realising that a terrible hosiery-based solecism had been committed?

item.title: Alex Brummer: Profoundly stupid act of economic vandalism
item.description: ALEX BRUMMER: There is one 'misstep', however, that stands out as profoundly stupid.That's the decision to quarantine incoming passengers to our airports...

item.title: The race to read your brain
item.description: As you lie sedated on the hospital bed, a robot's arm reaches out to the side of your head. Suddenly, a sharp beam of light springs out of its finger.

item.title: Two men die after being pulled from the River Avon in Bath
item.description: Emergency services were called at 4pm on Wednesday after it was reported that three people had fallen into the River Avon. Two men, believed to be in their 20s, were pronounced dead.

item.title: World's oldest 'bug' is a fossilized 425-million-year-old millipede discovered on a Scottish Island
item.description: Researchers discovered the world's oldest 'bug' on record - a 425-million-year-old fossilized millipede. It is 75 million years younger than previously estimated using a new dating technique.

item.title: Shocking moment gunmen faked being a couple and ambushed Mexican police officers in broad daylight
item.description: Two cops in Zacatecas, Mexico miraculously survived an ambush Sunday when four gunmen pretending to be two couples opened fire in the middle of street and fled.

item.title: Homebody billionaire Mark Zuckerberg says he has no interest in going to space
item.description: 'I'm not sure I'd want to go into space,' Zuckerberg told Fox News host Dana Perino on Thursday. 'I'm much more focused on virtual reality, which would let anyone teleport anywhere in the world.'

item.title: How Russian pilots came to train in Britain and took tea with a Duke, writes RICHARD PENDLEBURY
item.description: RICHARD PENDLEBURY: For decades after World War II, the story of the remarkable bond of friendship between British and Soviet soldiers previously told to hate each other was secret.

item.title: Salons are getting set to reopen but they're cutting all the little luxuries, writes JAN MOIR
item.description: JAN MOIR: I am lucky! Many friends and colleagues are trapped in a hair hell, looking like heads of frisee lettuce or shaggy mushrooms, with exposed roots, knotweed curls and worse.

item.title: National Trust to reopen some public gardens from next week ... but stately homes will stay shut
item.description: The National Trust will initially re-open gardens at 29 of its 500-plus heritage properties from June 3. The Royal Horticultural Society also announced it is opening its four gardens from June 1.

item.title: Dara McAnulty has the rare gift of evoking the natural world
item.description: Dara McAnulty, 17, from Northern Ireland, who is best known for running a popular blog about his adventures, has penned his first book, Diary Of A Young Naturalist.

item.title: Friends, flowers and foolproof pastry
item.description: British garden designer Jo Thompson and cook Mary Jane Paterson have penned a new book offering their expert cooking and gardening advice.

item.title: Andre Leon Talley thought the love of his fashionista friends would last for ever
item.description: Andre Leon Talley who grew up in Durham, North Carolina, reflects on his life in a fascinating new memoir. He details how his relationship with fashion industry insiders came to an end.

item.title: Author pens fascinating tome charting the history behind his family's wealth
item.description: Richard Atkinson who lives in London, has penned a book that delves into his family history. He was inspired after discovering a box that revealed his ancestors once owned slaves.

item.title: Mail Force has flown one million masks into the UK... and they've already reached the NHS frontline
item.description: Just 24 hours after touching down in Britain, the latest Mail Force charity airlift was already reaching the NHS frontline yesterday. The message from the recipients was clear - 'Thanks a million'.

item.title: Man charged with murder of girl found dead in Hampshire woods
item.description: Shane Mays, 29, of Havant, Hants, who was originally arrested on suspicion of kidnapping 16-year-old Louise Smith, also from Havant, has been charged with the teenager's murder.

item.title: Coronavirus US: Trump 'would take hydroxychloroquine again'
item.description: President Donald Trump is feeling 'perfect' after a two-week regime of hydroxychloroquine and would take it again even after Dr. Anthony Fauci said it was not an effective treatment for coronavirus.

item.title: Australian startup testing new fertilizer made out of repurposed alkaline batteries
item.description: An Australian company has developed a way to make enhanced fertilizer using repurposed alkaline batteries components, which they hope could lessen the burden of old batteries on landfills.

item.title: Elon Musk spent three to four YEARS developing the white 'tuxedo' SpaceX suits
item.description: NASA astronauts suited up in SpaceX suits for the Wednesday Falcon 9 launch that Elon Musk said he worked on for 'three to four years,' and envisioned it to resemble a heroic tuxedo.

item.title: Emily Maitlis seen out in London after Dominic Cummings scandal
item.description: The BBC is claimed to have had thousands of complaints about Ms Maitlis (pictured in London today) from Newsnight viewers but the corporation is refusing to release any figures.

item.title: Presence of Proxima b is CONFIRMED by scientists who say it may have liquid water and host life
item.description: Scientists have confirmed the presence of the Earth-like planet Proxima b. The team determined it receives the same amount of energy from its star as Earth does from the sun, suggesting it may host life.

item.title: Fast radio bursts reveal hidden low-density hot gas spread across the space between galaxies
item.description: The so-called 'missing baryon problem' emerged when cosmologists in the late nineties predicted that 5 per cent of the universe should be made of normal matter - but not enough appeared to be present..

item.title: Auction reveals story of British WWI captain's who helped the White Army during Russian civil war
item.description: Medals and photographs belonging to Birmingham-born Captain William Richardson revealed his role in helping fight communist Bolsheviks alongside the White Army in the Russian Civil War.

item.title: People's Covid-19 risk should be scored on a scale from 1 to 5
item.description: The idea - floated by experts from Bristol and Cambridge universities - would involve rating each person's chances of getting infected and dying from infection based on clear risk factors.

item.title: Breath-taking moment RAF's elite Red Arrows display team perform loop manoeuvre
item.description: Video shows Squadron leader Adam Collins flying alongside the crew near their base in RAF Scampton. Team photographer Corporal Adam Fletcher captured the Arrival Loop.

item.title: Ex-Labour spin chief Alastair Campbell is slammed for 'taking the p***' out of veterans
item.description: The two-minute video, which was posted to Twitter this afternoon, captures Campbell as he impersonates the Prime Minister recounting a bizarre meeting with the Queen.

item.title: New type of womb contraction in pregnant women could be a sign of pre-eclampsia
item.description: Researchers from the Nottingham University said blood flowed slowly through the placenta in healthy pregnancies, but in pre-eclampsia it was much more varied.

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch 'companion' says the pedophile financier killed himself
item.description: Former inmate Bill Mersey, who spent hours with Jeffrey Epstein at New York City's Metropolitan Correctional Center, says he died by suicide in his jail cell, despite murder conspiracy theories.

item.title: Chris Whitty and Sir Patrick Vallance say they 'don't want to get involved' in Cummings row
item.description: Durham Police today said Mr Cummings' 260-mile trip to Durham did not break lockdown rules while a 60-mile jaunt to a beauty spot only 'might have'.

item.title: Mom accidentally flashes seven-year-old's classmates on Zoom
item.description: Ashley Foret Smith from Jacksonville, Florida shared the embarrassing moment in a viral Facebook video after her seven-year-old daughter surprised her.

item.title: Trees are 'getting shorter due to climate change', study claims
item.description: More wildfires, droughts and insect swarms combined with higher temperatures have reduced the lifespan of trees, scientists at the University of Birmingham said.

item.title: Antarctic ice sheets retreated up to 50 metres a DAY at the end of the last Ice Age
item.description: Cambridge University experts used patterns of wave-like ridges on the Antarctic seafloor to calculate how quickly the ice sheets melted around 12,000 years ago.

item.title: Coronavirus England: Primary schools to reopen from Monday
item.description: Boris Johnson today announced the phased reopening of primary schools in England will begin as planned on Monday.

item.title: Cat dubbed the 'Beast of Billionaire's Row' may be EATING tycoons' pets to survive, neighbour claims
item.description: Armed officers and a helicopter were deployed in the hunt for the animal when it was spotted in north London earlier this week.

item.title: Baby girl has second mouth with lips, teeth and tongue removed
item.description: WARNING GRAPHIC CONTENT. The 0.8-inch mass was spotted at week 28 of pregnancy but thought to be a cyst. She was born in Charleston, South Carolina.
item.media:credit: Alexandra O Hamberis; David Macias; Clarice Clemmens; Krishna G Patel / BMJ

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Boris Johnson accused of silencing experts
item.description: Durham Police have said that Dominic Cummings did break lockdown rules when he travelled 50 miles to Barnard Castle.

item.title: Tony Scannell dead: The Bill star passes away aged 74
item.description: The Irish actor's cause of death has not yet been revealed, but his passing was confirmed by a friend, who posted a Facebook tribute on Wednesday. He is survived by his partner Agnes Lillis.

item.title: Woman shares photo with boyfriend flashing in the background
item.description: Shannon Butt, 22,from Gloucestershire, was left crying with laughter after she noticed her boyfriend wiping his bottom in the background of one of her selfies.- and posted the hilarious results on Twitter.

item.title: JANET STREET-PORTER: Good luck with Test and Trace
item.description: The Government is using a life-threatening virus as an excuse to authorise a huge level of intrusion into our personal lives, writes JANET STREET-PORTER.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Government's contact tracing site crashes
item.description: Doctors and other staff reported major teething troubles as the much-trumpeted scheme finally got up and running, with some saying they had not even received passwords to start work.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Matt Hancock laughs about contact tracing app
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock was told it was 'not a laughing matter' as he chuckled at suggestions he had rushed the system in before it is actually ready.

item.title: Amir Khan flouts lockdown rules AGAIN for family reunion after 18 month feud
item.description: The boxer, his wife Faryal Makhdoom and their three children visited his parents at their home in Bolton earlier this week to celebrate Eid al-Fitr.

item.title: Couple travel world to find movie locations and recreate scenes, from Forest Gump to La La Land
item.description: Robin Lachhein and Judith Schneider, from Germany, post images of their amazing recreations to their Instagram page, Secret Famous Places, which has a following of more than 20,000 people.

item.title: LG Poland apologises for posting 'upskirting' phone ad
item.description: LG Poland was forced to apologise for a lewd video it posted on short video platform TikTok earlier this week. The 12-second clip showed a young woman being photographed as she walked up stairs.
item.media:credit: GRABS: LG advert from Poland shows man creepily taking upstart pictures

item.title: Iranian state media accused of editing photo of 13-year-old beheaded by her father
item.description: Romina Ashrafi, 13, was beheaded by her father with a sickle in an apparent honour killing - before an Iranian newspaper apparently photoshopped an image of her to hide her hair.

item.title: How will the coronavirus test and trace system work?
item.description: The much-delayed scheme was unveiled at yesterday's coronavirus press conference by Health Secretary Matt Hancock, who said it was the 'civic duty' of the public to adhere to the new rules.
